{{Infobox_ancient_site | name = Sonari Stupas | native_name = Sonari | alternate_name = | image = Sonari stupa n°2 with stupa n°1 in the background.jpg | imagealttext = Stupa # 2, and stupa # 1 in the background, Sonari | caption = Sonari stupa n°2 with stupa n°1 in the background. | map_type = India | map_alt = | coordinates = {{coord|23|25|56|N|77|39|51|E|display=inline, title}} | location = | region = | type = Buddhist settlement | part_of = | length = | width = | area = | height = | builder = | material = | built = | abandoned = | epochs = | cultures = | dependency_of = | occupants = | event = | excavations = | archaeologists = | condition = | ownership = | public_access = | website = | notes = }} '''Sonari''' is the archaeological site of an ancient monastic complex of [[Buddhist]] [[stupa]]s. The site, positioned on a hill, is located about 10km southwest of [[Sanchi]], [[Madhya Pradesh]], [[India]].<ref name = "ASI"> [http://www.asibhopal.nic.in/monument/raisen_Sonari_buddhistacentland.html ASI Sonari page]</ref>
== History == The stupas were excavated around 1850 by [[Alexander Cunningham]], who discovered two boxes containing relics.<ref> [http://www.bl.uk/onlinegallery/onlineex/apac/other/019wdz000000546u00003a00.html British Library Online] </ref> One of the reliquaries, which is very ornate, is visible nowadays at the [[Victoria and Albert Museum]].
The reliquary of Stupa No.2 presents has inscriptions in [[Brahmi]] mentioning the names of Buddhist monks also appearing in the reliquary of [[Sanchi Stupa No.2]] and [[Andher Stupas]]: Kasapagota, Majjhima, Kosikiputa, Gotiputa, and Apagira.<ref name = "BA"> Huu Phuoc's Buddhist Architecture The [https://books.google.com/books?id=9jb364g4BvoC&pg=PA148 p.148] </ref> It would seem, then, that the ashes of these monks were divided between these three stupas.
The date of construction of Stupa 1 and Stupa 2 must therefore be equivalent to those of [[Sanchi Stupa No.2]], i.e. 125-100 BCE.<Ref name = "BA"/>
There are in all four groups of stupas surrounding Sanchi within a radius of twenty kilometers: Bhojpur and Andher to the southeast, Sonari to the southwest, and Satdhara in the west. <ref name ="BC"> Buddhist Circuit in Central India: Sanchi, Satdhara, Sonari, Andher, Travel ... [https://books.google.fr/books?id=TOrKExVXXpkC&pg=PT3& p31 </ref> Further south, about 100 km away, is [[Saru Maru]].
<Gallery> Sanchi and surrounding stupas.jpg|Sanchi and surrounding stupas, including Sonari southwest of Sanchi. Sonari stupas map.jpg|Plan of Sonari stupas. File:Sonari stupas.jpg|Small stupas in Sonari, and stupa No.1 in the background. Sonari stupa.jpg|One of the little stupas. </Gallery>
==Stupa No.1== Alexander Cunningham and FC Maisey searched Sonari's Stupa 1 in 1851. The stupa contained a miniature soapstone reliquary.
<Gallery> File:Sonari Stupa 1.jpg| Stupa No.1 File:Sonari stupa 1 section and plan.jpg |Plan of excavations of stupa No.1 File:Sonari Stupa 1 and relics.jpg|Reliquary of Stupa No.1 Sonari pillar.jpg|Decorated pillar of Sonari stupa No.1 </Gallery>
== Stupa No.2 == [[File:Sonari Stupa 2 reliquary.jpg|thumb|The main reliquary of Stupa No.2 at [[Victoria and Albert Museum]] [https://collections.vam.ac.uk/item/O25176/reliquary-unknown/].]] Alexander Cunningham and FC Maisey searched Sonari's Stupa No.2 in 1851. The stupa contained three miniature reliquaries, two in soapstone and one in rock crystal, as well as a certain amount of bone ash and a piece of wood. The main reliquary is shaped to resemble a [[Lotus (plant)|lotus]] bud, with incised petals decorating the lower half of the reliquary. It was turned on a [[lathe]] and then carved in [[bas-relief]] with lotus petal strips on the shoulder and lower body, while on the upper body is a large area divided into eight rectangular compartments in each of which are an elephant, horse, deer or winged lion, patterns typical of the period of the [[Maurya Empire]]. These discoveries were published by A Cunningham in ''The Bhilsa Topes'' in 1854.<ref name = "VA"> Notice from [[Victoria and Albert Museum]] [https://collections.vam.ac.uk/item/O25176/reliquary-unknown/] </ref>
It had been customary since the death of the Buddha to preserve and venerate his relics. Under emperor [[Ashoka]] (around 268-233 BCE), converted to Buddhism and energetic protector of the faith, a series of stupas, mounds of relics, were erected throughout the empire, marking sites important in the life of the Buddha. This practice continued, and this container of relics was buried around 200 BCE. Relic deposits of this period usually represented original deposits of the relics of the Buddha.<ref name = "VA"/>
<Gallery> File:Sonari Stupa 2.jpg|Stupa No.2 Sonari stupa 2 section and plan.jpg|Section and plan. Sonari stupa 2 relics.jpg|Relics of Stupa No.2. Sonari Stupa 2 and relics.jpg|Relics of Stupa No.2. </Gallery>
{{Adjacent communities |title=Adjacent Buddhist structures | Centre = [[Sanchi]] | N = | E = [[Bhojpur Stupas]] |SE=[[Andher Stupas]] | S = [[Saru Maru]] |SW=Sonari Stupas | W = [[Satdhara]] }}

'''Symbolic Systems''' is an academic program at [[Stanford University]] with an [[interdisciplinarity |interdisciplinary]] concentration on "the science of the mind" including courses in [[computer science]], [[linguistics]], [[philosophy]], and [[psychology]].<ref name=Martinuzzi>{{cite web|last1=Martinuzzi|first1=Bruna|title=Symbolic Systems: The Hot Major Among Highly Successful People|url=https://www.americanexpress.com/us/small-business/openforum/articles/symbolic-systems-the-hot-major-among-highly-successful-people/|website=OPEN Forum|publisher=American Express|accessdate=29 November 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151129175504/https://www.americanexpress.com/us/small-business/openforum/articles/symbolic-systems-the-hot-major-among-highly-successful-people/|archivedate=2015-11-29|date=September 18, 2013|quote=It's a multidisciplinary major that blends computer science with psychology, linguistics and philosophy |deadurl=no}}</ref><ref name=Whatis>{{cite web|title=What is Sym Sys?|url=https://symsys.stanford.edu/ssp_description|website=Symbolic Systems Program|publisher=Stanford University|accessdate=29 November 2015|quote=majors are required to take courses in the Departments of Computer Science, Linguistics, Philosophy, and Psychology}}</ref> The program is analogous to [[cognitive science]] departments at other schools.
The program offers both bachelor's and master's degrees. The undergraduate major is split into concentrations such as artificial intelligence, human-computer interaction, decision making and rationality, and neuroscience. Student advisors and the student-led Symbolic Systems Society provide support and organize events for the major.<ref name=Society>{{cite web|title=SymSys Society Homepage|url=http://www.symsyssociety.org/|website=Symbolic Systems Society|accessdate=3 February 2018}}</ref> Each year, the program hosts a "Distinguished Speaker", which in the past have included Daniel Dennett, Steven Pinker, Edward Snowden, and Marvin Minsky.<ref name=Disting>{{cite web|title=Symbolic Systems Distinguished Speaker|url=https://symsys.stanford.edu/viewing/htmldocument/13638|website=Symbolic Systems Program|publisher=Stanford University|accessdate=3 February 2018}}</ref>
==Notable graduates== *[[Chris Cox (Facebook)|Chris Cox]], Chief Product Officer at Facebook *[[Scott Forstall]] *[[Reid Hoffman]]<ref name=Martinuzzi /> *[[Mike Krieger]]<ref name=Martinuzzi /> *[[Yul Kwon]] *[[Marissa Mayer]]<ref name=Martinuzzi /><ref>{{cite web | url=http://engineering.stanford.edu/press/marissa-mayer-named-ceo-of-yahoo | title=Marissa Mayer named CEO of Yahoo! | publisher=Stanford Engineering | date=16 July 2012 | accessdate=18 August 2014 | author=Dulce, Grace | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140819125932/http://engineering.stanford.edu/press/marissa-mayer-named-ceo-of-yahoo | archivedate=19 August 2014 | df= }}</ref> *[[Yuko Munakata]] *[[Srinija Srinivasan]] *[[Tina Chen]] *[[Barney Pell]] *[[Tony Tulathimutte]] *[[Dalton Caldwell]]

{{Orphan|date=February 2009}} A '''troop density''' ({{lang-ru|Плотность войск}}) also known as the ''dispersion factor'' in [[military science]] is a [[Statistics#Experimental and observational studies|statistical value]] assigned by commanders during the [[combat operations process]] in considering the ability of the [[Combat Arms]] to achieve [[Goal|military objectives]] during a [[military operation]]. It reflects [[combat readiness]] of the [[unit (military)|units]] to participate in [[engagement (military)|engagements]] with consideration to the [[Tactical Area of Responsibility|terrain]] and expected enemy strength.
The [[Units of measurement|unit of measurement]] is square metres per [[soldier]], although this is modified for each combat arm to reflect their primary [[weapon performance]] in combat as [[weapon density]] ({{lang-ru|Плотность оружия}});<ref>cf.p.243, Naveh</ref> for example [[artillery|guns]] for artillery.<ref>pp.84-85, Dupuy</ref> Troop density is also used to [[Intelligence analysis|estimate]] forces required to occupy a given populated territory in order to deny this population to being exploited by the enemy [[Covert operation|covert forces]] or insurgent troops.<ref>p.16, McGrath</ref>
The troop density has decreased through [[military history]] in proportion to the increase in [[weapon lethality|lethality of weapons]] being use in combat.<ref>pp.84-85, Dupuy</ref> However, there is no accepted standard to calculate this value due to the large number of variables involved in the planning of combat operations.<ref>p.93, McGrath</ref>
Military history can be divided into three periods according to ''average troop density'' employed in [[combat]]: ancient armies with about 10 square metres per foot soldier, the age of [[close order formation]] armed with firearms encompassing the period from the 1650s to the [[Franco-Prussian War]] of 1871 that increased the average to 250 square meters per [[infantryman]], and the [[Second World War]] when the density decreased to 27,500 square metres per [[infantryman]].<ref>p.84, Dupuy</ref> The [[Soviet Army]] has based much of its post-war doctrine on the war experience, and had devoted considerable resources to the analysis of troop density, including these in almost all considerations of wartime operations.<ref>for example during strategic offensives to liberate Poland, p.295, Chaney</ref> By the end of the [[Cold War]] the density (in Europe) was estimated to be 50,000 square metres per [[infantryman]] due to widespread [[mechanised infantry|mechanisation]] of forces.<ref>p.84, Dupuy</ref>
Troop density was included in the [[Military doctrine|doctrine]] of the [[First World War]] belligerents, based on the [[battalion]] per [[forward zone]] front calculation.<ref>p.216, Samuels</ref> The density of troops also affects the planning of [[close air support]] operations because of the higher rate of missions required to deliver adequate munitions to their targets.<ref>p.123, Brown</ref> The increased dispersal of troops was the consideration behind the decision to develop [[nuclear bomb]]s before effects of radiation were realised.<ref>p.65, Bellamy</ref>
The physical density of troops in the area of combat is not reflective of the average value for any given [[Command (military formation)|command]] because dispersion of troops tends to follow [[terrain]] and [[military tactics|tactical]] considerations of the combat planning, and actual location of troops tends to be in clusters of [[position (military)|positions]].<ref>p.191, Hughes</ref> Low troop density is a particular problem as a period of vulnerability during [[air assault]], [[air landing]], [[amphibious assault]] and to some extent [[airborne assault]] operations,<ref>p.32, McCall & Corder</ref> as well as during pre-combat concentration of troops in the [[staging area]] prior to their movement to the battle area, denying them [[operational mobility]].<ref>p.64, National Research Council</ref>
